page.title: 16THE SAW-MILL
page.content: The Saw-mill in the Park has been a commercial concern since 1930. Seven men are employed there to deal with hard and soft wood from the 8,000 acres of near-by forest. Hard wood, mainly oak, which thrives on the areas of London clay, is used for making into fences, park benches and garden furniture. Some wood is sold for rustic poles while other large beams are in demand for conserving and making reproduction Tudor buildings. Architects like the "green" wood straight from the mill, preferably with a fungus disease which will make the wood look black quickly. Mostly the mill sells planks of wood to the general public. Soft wood from the area of Bagshot Sand is brought to the park from the other saw-mill near Ascot for treatment.
